occurrences.line_text: In beastly vse that I did euer find;
And he thereby, where euer it in field was showne.
And euer in your noble hart prepense,
And breaking quite his gyrlond euer greene,
Next Saturne was, (but who would euer weene,
That sullein Saturne euer weend to loue?
Expecting euer, when some foe she might descry.
And euer as Dissemblance laught on him,
Boue all her sexe that euer yet was seene;
But none more piteous euer was ytold,
As euer could Cameleon colours new;
Be thou, where euer thou do go or ryde,
And euer when his passion is allayd,
Forgetfull each to haue bene euer others frend.
How euer gay and goodly be the style,
That euer shrilling trumpet did resound;
That none durst euer whilest thou wast aliue,
Ne euer was with fond affection moued,
And loue each other deare, what euer them befell.
Yet whilest they liued none did euer see
Did euer see vpon this world to shine,
And plighted hands for euer friends to be.
Ne was there Knight that euer thought of armes,
And beating downe, what euer nigh him came,
And ouerthrew, what euer came her neare,
It hath bene through all ages euer seene,
Giue it to her, for euer to remaine,
Which vertue it for euer after did retaine.
For euer as they fastned it, it loos'd
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
The fayrest Ladie reft, and euer since withheld.
From foule mischance; ne did it euer rest,
What yron courage euer could endure,
But euer when his visage she beheld,
Ne euer was there wight to me more deare
How euer she her paynd with womanish art
And yeelded leaue, how euer malcontent
Whose bodies chast, when euer in his powre
(Quoth she) of all that euer hath bene knowen:
Equall to this, where euer I haue gone.
Both sire, and friends, and all for euer to forego.
For euer when he burnt in lustfull fire,
For euer when the Squire his iauelin shooke,
And euer in her bow she ready shewed
Ne thenceforth euer strike in battell stroke,
Ne euer word to speake to woman more;
Ne other drinke there did he euer tast,
And euer when the Prince vnto him spake,
He euer tasted, but with penaunce sad
Ne euer laught, ne once shew'd countenance glad;
And euer when she nigh approcht, the Doue
Ne euer Knight so bold, ne euer Dame
Ne euer Knight so bold, ne euer Dame
Ne euer thing so well was doen aliue,
Ne was he euer vanquished afore,
But euer vanquisht all, with whom he fought;
So faire, as euer yet saw liuing eie:
A sunder, yet not euer in one place,
Diuided them, how euer loth to rest,
To whom the world this franchise euer yeelded,
Whom seeking euer since with endlesse paines,
Whose right she is, where euer she be straide,
True he it said, what euer man it sayd,
So all that euer yet I haue endured,
VVhose euer be the shield, faire Amoret be his.
For ought that euer she could doe or say,
That euer troden was of footings trace.
Ne euer ought but of their true loues talkt,
Ne euer for rebuke or blame of any balkt.
All these and all that euer had bene tyde,
In bands of friendship, there did liue for euer,
That euer were on earth, all were they set together.
Ne euer durst her eyes from ground vpreare,
Ne euer once did looke vp from her desse,
That euer she to me could say or doe,
Ne euer euening saw, ne mornings ray,
Ne euer from the day the night descride,
Then shine in learning, more then euer did
So euer loose, so euer happy be.
So euer loose, so euer happy be.
But promist him, what euer wight she weare,
And doe what euer thing he did intend.
A sorie sight, as euer seene with eye;
That euer I this dismall day did see:
Ne euer Artegall his griple strong
How euer gay their blossome or their blade
Ne euer any asketh reason why.
What euer thing is done, by him is donne,
Yet the least word that euer could be layd
For truth is one, and right is euer one.
Whom euer as he did the more auize,
But I will it defend, whilst euer that I may.
That euer in this wretched case ye were?
My law, and euer to my lore be bound;
What euer he shall like to doe or say.
How euer it his noble heart did gall,
And, though (vnlike) they should for euer last,
I to your selfe should rest for euer bound,
And let, what euer he desires, be him denide.
Ne euer did deceiptfull Clarin find
That no new loues impression euer could
And tell what euer it be, good or bad,
Nor good nor bad, ne euer lookt aside,
Where euer in the darke he could them spie;
That vnder Isis feete doth sleepe for euer:
For her no other termes should euer tie
And therefore ought it haue, where euer she it fond.
For all that euer came within his reach,
And that they should for euer faithfull bee,
Went on his way, ne euer howre did cease,
Ne day nor night did euer idly rest;
And euer as she rode, her eye was backeward bent.
How euer loth he were his way to slake,
By like ensample mote for euer warned bee.
There let her euer keepe her damned den,
Full dreadfull wight he was, as euer went
And euer round about he cast his looke.
He him pursewd, where euer that he went,
That euer yet vpon this earth was seene,
Or that with Diademe hath euer crowned beene.
Ne euer was the name of warre there spoken,
But walkt about them euer and anone,
To doe, what euer he thought good or fit.
Much greater then was euer in her weeting,
And euer ere he saw the stroke to land,
Whose vgly shape none euer saw, nor kend,
That euer scap'd: for of a man they say
Whereto she euer list to make her hardy flight.
Could euer loose, but suffred deadly doole.
On which long way he rode, ne euer day did rest.
And forced them, how euer strong and stout
Sith which she hath me euer since abhord,
Ay me, that euer guyle in wemen was inuented.
Ne euer any found his match in might;
He shund his strokes, where euer they did fall,
Nathlesse, for all that euer he could doe,
That euer she sees doen prays-worthily,
But this, what euer euill she conceiued,
A shamefull vse as euer I did heare,
How euer strong and fortunate in fight,
How can he mercy euer hope to haue?
He vp arose, how euer liefe or loth,
Who euer thinkes through confidence of might,
Sonne of a King, how euer thorough fate
From him, to whom she was for euer bound:
That thou for euer doe those armes forsake,
And be for euer held a recreant Knight,
That curtesie and manhood euer disagree.
Then Calepine, how euer inly wroth,
As euer he to Lady was affyde,
Who euer, as he saw him nigh succeed,
Ne fed on flesh, ne euer of wyld beast
What euer formes ye list thereto apply,
She bore it thence, and euer as her owne it kept.
The gentle bloud, how euer it be wrapt
Ne euer saw faire guize, ne learned good,
How euer by hard hap he hether came;
And euer more and more her owne affliction wrought.
Ne euer shewed signe of foule disloyalty.
It euer can recured be againe;
It euer to amend: ne maruaile ought;
Ne euer Knight, that bore so lofty creast,
Ne euer Lady of so honest name,
Ne would the Prince him euer foot forsake,
That euer I this life vnto thee lent,
Ne euer armes, ne euer knighthood dare
Ne euer armes, ne euer knighthood dare
And both combynd, what euer chaunce were blowne,
That euer I for meed did vndertake
How euer they through treason doe trespasse.
And so would euer liue, and loue her owne delight.
The greatest shame that euer eye yet saw?
Ne euer had such knightly seruice seene,
Had euer learn'd to loue the lowly things,
Then all that he could doe, or euer deuize:
And euer when him came in companie,
Ne euer shewed signe of rancour or of iarre.
With whom he myndes for euer to remaine,
For all that euer was by natures skill
Did her beseeme. And euer, as the crew
What euer thing he did her to aggrate,
Most sorrowfull, most sad, that euer sigh't,
That euer liu'd, and th'onely glory of his might.
The ioyes of loue, if they should euer last,
But all that euer he could doe or say,
Ne ought would buy, how euer prisd with measure,
For that same mayd, how euer it him greeues,
That euer I did liue, this day to see,
How could the death dare euer her to quell?
A lustie knight, as euer wielded speare,
Who euer is the mother of one chylde,
And snar at all, that euer passed by:
Nor euer thought thing so vnworthily:
Ne euer any durst till then impose,
Ne euer could by any more be brought
Yet none of them could euer bring him into band.
The euer-burning lamps from thence it braught,
And leading th'euer-burning lampe astray,
And euer-drizling raine vpon the loft,
In siluer deaw his euer-drouping hed,
From tyrans rage, and euer-dying dread,
The Lyon Lord of euerie beast in field,
Then panting soft, and trembling euerie ioynt,
That euerie word did tremble as she spake,
And euerie looke was coy, and wondrous quaint,
And euerie limbe that touched her did quake:
Well seene in euerie science that mote bee,
For euerie thing, to which one is inclin'd,
Whylest euerie one with helping hands did striue
Lay forth out of thine euerlasting scryne
Now in the powre of euerlasting Night?
The Nourse of time, and euerlasting fame,
And life eke euerlasting did befall:
Lifting to heauen her euerlasting fame:
Let vs deuize of ease and euerlasting rest.
Ioy may you haue, and euerlasting fame,
And bid them sleepe in euerlasting peace.
With recompence of euerlasting fame.
Then woe, and woe, and euerlasting woe,
But still remaines in euerlasting store,
There now he liues in euerlasting ioy,
From heauens blisse and euerlasting rest;
In euerlasting moniments of brasse,
Where she hath now an euerlasting place,
Sith in th'Almighties euerlasting seat
To see the man, whose euerlasting praise
With burning starres, and euerliuing fire,
He told of Saintes and Popes, and euermore
Her, whom he waking euermore did weene,
And sighes, and grones, and euermore does steepe
Well to accept, and euermore embrace
Till then: for euermore she hated, neuer loued.
And slake the heauenly fire, that raged euermore.
As rocke of Diamond stedfast euermore.
Yet euermore it was his manner faire,
And euermore in constant carefull mind
My simple selfe, and seruice euermore;
It gouernd was, and guided euermore,
But thankt be God, and her encrease so euermore.
His owne deare Vna hearing euermore
Their gates to all were open euermore,
That shall ye euermore renowmed make,
Where she enioyes sure peace for euermore,
Ne ought would speake, but euermore did seeme
And eue[r]more with mighty spels them charmd,
And euermore himselfe with comfort feedes,
Him followed eke Sir Guyon euermore,
But euermore him succour, and defend
And euermore their cruell Capitaine
In which he them defeated euermore,
Against the fort of reason euermore
And euermore their hideous Ordinance
And euermore their wicked Capitaine
That seem'd to tremble euermore, and quake:
Which drawing backe, he looked euermore
And lowd to them for succour called euermore.
Makes for him endlesse mone, and euermore
So euermore he did increase his speed,
But euermore she him refused flat,
Of readie entrance, which ought euermore
And euermore the Carle of curtesie accusd.
And with the like him answerd euermore:
Fashioning worlds of fancies euermore
But euermore and more vpon it gazed,
And euermore on daunger fixt his eye,
And euermore encreased her consuming paine.
Whom mortally he hated euermore,
Mongst gentle Knights to nourish euermore?
And euermore sought Britomart to cleare.
But euermore, when she fit time could fynd,
Yet euermore his honour he recured,
About the Andvile standing euermore,
And euermore, when he to sleepe did thinke,
And euermore, when he began to winke,
And euermore from villenie her kept:
And euermore when with regardfull sight
But turnd her face, and fled away for euermore.
And euermore, when he did grace entreat,
Him seeking euermore, yet no where him descride.
And euermore he greatly did desire
But euermore their malice did augment;
And euermore his eyes about him went,
But in the Porch did euermore abide
Braue thoughts and noble deedes did euermore aspire.
And euermore vpon the Goddesse face
But euermore my shield did me defend,
But euermore some of the vertuous race
And as his Squire him offred euermore
But euermore, those Damzels did forestall
And euermore he gently did desyre,
So praying him t'accept her seruice euermore.
And euermore she did him sharpely twight
To his inferiour Gods, and euermore
Yeeld for amends my selfe yours euermore,
To be a moniment for euermore.
And euermore those hags them selues did paine,
That shall you most renowmed make for euermore.
And her selfe bound to him for euermore;
But euermore contrary hath bene tryde,
And euermore his louely litle spoile
That in her soueraine lyking he dwelt euermore.
And euermore that crauen cowherd Knight
That made him euermore increase his speedie pace.
And euermore she blamed Calepine,
And euermore his speach he did apply
And euermore the shepheard Coridon,
Who as her owne it nurst, and named euermore.
She was in life and euery vertuous lore,
That euery wight to shrowd it did constrain,
But euery hill and dale, each wood and plaine
Sans foy: full large of limbe and euery ioint
And their greene leaues trembling with euery blast,
Till on a day (that day is euery Prime,
Nine hundred Pater nosters euery day,
Thrise euery weeke in ashes she did sit,
When euery creature shrowded is in sleepe;
That euery breath of heauen shaked it:
Thence to the hall, which was on euery side
Of Lordes and Ladies stood on euery side
From euery worke he chalenged essoyne,
So euery good to bad he doth abuse:
And softly can embalme on euery side.
Which passing through, on euery side them stood
Of feends infernall flockt on euery side,
Scattered on euery mountaine, as he went,
Did heale them all againe, and ioyned euery part.
And euery tender part for feare does shake:
Which quit from death yet quakes in euery lim
That euery beast for feare of him did fly and quake.
That suddein cold did runne through euery vaine,
And eke so faint in euery ioynt and vaine,
And euery tender part does tosse and turne:
Perce to my hart, and pas through euery side,
With foltring tong, and trembling euery vaine,
Whose tender locks do tremble euery one
At euery little breath, that vnder heauen is blowne.
From euery coast that heauen walks about,
But trembling feare did feele in euery vaine;
And euery dore of freewill open flew.
And euery head with fyrie tongue did flame,
And euery head was crowned on his creast,
And eger greedinesse through euery member thrild.
Those were the keyes of euery inner dore,
And did with store of euery thing abound,
Through euery rowme he sought, and euery bowr,
Through euery rowme he sought, and euery bowr,
Of death, that here lye dying euery stound,
And trembling horrour ran through euery ioynt,
To kindle loue in euery liuing brest;
Whiles euery sence the humour sweet embayd,
But trembling euery ioynt did inly quake,
Into the hart, and searcheth euery vaine,
Is not his law, Let euery sinner die:
Which when as Vna saw, through euery vaine
She vnto him disclosed euery whit,
And dieted with fasting euery day,
Was wont him once to disple euery day:
Gan him instruct in euery good behest,
That God to vs forgiueth euery howre
During which time, in euery good behest
And euery sinew seene through his long fast:
But that same end, which euery liuing wight
Send forth their flames farre off to euery shyre,
Then when with meates and drinkes of euery kinde
What if in euery other starre vnseene
Who feigning then in euery limbe to quake,
In euery fountaine, and in euery lake,
In euery fountaine, and in euery lake,
They stint their strife, and him assaile on euery side.
And euery one her with a grace endowes:
And euery one with meekenesse to her bowes.
Proudly to prune, and set on euery side,
Woe neuer wants, where euery cause is caught,
That seemd him to enflame on euery side:
And euery way did seeke into his life,
Therein the mery birds of euery sort
Euery of which did loosely disaray
And euery of them stroue, with most delights,
And doubling all his powres, redoubled euery stroke.
That euery weightie thing they did vpbeare,
Of euery place, that was with brusing harmd,
And round about him lay on euery side
And with rich metall loaded euery rift,
On euery side they placed were along.
By euery fornace many feends did bide,
And euery feend his busie paines applide,
And euery one did swincke, and euery one did sweat.
And euery one did swincke, and euery one did sweat.
And euery pillour decked was full deare
Of euery sort and nation vnder skye,
And euery lincke thereof a step of dignity.
But euery one did striue his fellow downe to throw.
And euery loup fast lockt, as fearing foes despight.
And round about the porch on euery side
But at these straungers presence euery one did hush.
Which through the world the[m] swarmd in euery part,
And health to euery forreine nation:
Who him at first well vsed euery way;
Might looke, that maketh euery creature glad,
That castle to assaile on euery side,
As euery one seem'd meetest in that cace.
And euery one of them had Lynces eyes,
And euery one did bow and arrowes beare:
On euery side floting the floods emong:
Both firmely armd for euery hard assay,
A large and spacious plaine, on euery side
Through euery channell running one might see;
Loosely disperst with puffe of euery blast:
And sore beset on euery side around,
But stoutly dealt his blowes, and euery way
That euery knight, which doth this way repaire,
Of euery pillour and of euery post;
Of euery pillour and of euery post;
Of appetite with meates of euery sort,
And euery knight, and euery gentle Squire
And euery knight, and euery gentle Squire
High time it seemed then for euery wight
Vnto their bowres to guiden euery guest:
Yshrowded was, and euery mortall wight
Of euery finest fingers touch affrayd;
Here, there, and euery where about her swayd
And euery daintie limbe with horrour shake;
And him in euery part before her fashioned.
Yet him in euery part before she knew,
And euery riuer eke his course forbeares
And euery trembling ioynt, and euery vaine
And euery trembling ioynt, and euery vaine
For thy she gaue him warning euery day,
And euery one did teare her girlond from her crowne.
And great Dame Natures handmaide, chearing euery kind.
And euery one to runne the swiftest stryu'd;
Of euery thing consumes, and calcineth by art.
And seized euery sense with sorrow sore opprest.
And searched euery way, through which his wings
Ladies and Lords she euery where mote heare
And euery one did aske, did he him see;
And euery one her answerd, that too late
And euery one threw forth reproches rife
So saying euery Nymph full narrowly she eyde.
Throughout the wandring forrest euery where:
And euery sort is in a sundry bed
For euery substance is conditioned
And all about grew euery sort of flowre,
And euery leafe, that shaketh with the least
And euery where, where with my power or skill
Who seem'd for feare to quake in euery lim,
For euery shape on him he could endew:
In th'heart of euery honourable Dame,
Yet euery one her likte, and euery one her loued.
Yet euery one her likte, and euery one her loued.
And euery one his kindred, and his name.
Euery discourse and euery argument,
Euery discourse and euery argument,
Yet warily he watcheth euery way,
And seest euery secret of the mind;
He courted her, yet bayted euery word,
And euery where he might, and euery while
And euery where he might, and euery while
And euery where that he mote vnderstond,
That euery member of his bodie quooke.
And euery one as commune good her handeled.
But euery Satyre first did giue a busse
That euery bird and beast awarned made,
Who butted him with hornes on euery syde,
Hatefull both to him selfe, and euery wight;
The wood they enter, and search euery where,
Yet here, and there, and euery where vnwares
The raging billowes, that on euery syde
Be bold, be bold, and euery where Be bold,
That euery wight dismayd with darknesse sad,
Throughout the house, that clapped euery dore,
And euery wood, and euery valley wyde
And euery wood, and euery valley wyde
And euery part to safety full sound,
Amidst the bridale feast, whilest euery man
And euery one gan grow in secret dout
That still are led with euery light report.
Was so expert in euery subtile slight,
The couenant was, that euery spoyle or pray
And euery secret worke of natures wayes,
Still watcht on euery side, of secret foes affrayd.
That euery houre they knocke at deathes gate?
At puffe of euery storme doth stagger here and theare.
Like as it seemed best to euery one;
That euery one gan shun his dreadfull sight,
That dreadfull seem'd to euery liuing wight,
So euery place seem'd painefull, and ech changing vaine.
Tho gan he swell in euery inner part,
And lashing dreadfully at euery part,
There they her sought, and euery where inquired,
Yet trembling euery ioynt through former feare;
And vnto euery thing did aunswere mum:
And eke by that he saw on euery tree,
And euery day for guerdon of her song,
Came to that Squire, yet trembling euery vaine:
To whom the keyes of euery prison dore
As if that euery dint the ghost would riue
For euery dram of hony therein found,
There worshipped of euery liuing wight;
Euery of which was to a damzell hight;
